posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: When using follower modes in CTRE and REV if I use position control, velocity control, etc will the motors follow or will they only follow if I use direct voltage or current control.  I ask because both vendor examples don’t show using their own velocity/position control modes.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: This seems like the perfect thing to test empirically (without a mechanical link between the two motors to avoid damage)

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Agreed, I just wanted to know if it was already the case.  Like with CTRE if I use PositionVoltage requests.  Does the following motor comply.  Or am I limited to VoltageOut requests, etc.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: I would be surprised if it didnt work that way. But definitely test to confirm.
Can confirm that it works with Rev. Have not tested CTRE on this.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Steven Carmain
Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
I believe follower mode is implemented via communication between the motors, not originating from requests from the RIO.

What I mean is, if I tell B to follow A, A will broadcast its duty-cycle at some frequency, and B will listen to that value and set its own to the same value (with an optional polarity flip).

Regardless of how A’s output is determined (direct voltage, duty cycle, feedback control) B will follow A’s duty-cycle command.

posts.name: Steven Carmain
posts.cooked: To my knowledge, this is correct.  I believe they do this as the one motor actually watches the CAN frames of the primary and reacts to them as if it was that ID.  It makes follower mode almost “free” on the CAN bus.
